Award.AwardTitle: Re-evaluating Mechanisms of RNA-mediated Initiation of Transposable Element Silencing in Plants

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Transposable elements are DNA fragments in a genome that can mobilize and create mutations by inserting into new locations. To guard against this mutagenic outcome, cells have evolved mechanisms to interfere with transposable element mobilization. Previous work established a role for small RNAs in transposable element inhibition. This project will use modern genomics-enabled approaches in the model plant, Arabidopsis thaliana, to conduct a 'severe test' of the assumptions and conclusions that led to the prevailing mechanistic view and to expand understanding of how transposable element silencing is triggered. Because transposable elements are widespread in the genomes of both plants and animals, the results are expected to have broad impact in the field of regulatory biology. The project will also have strong educational impact, as it emphasizes data reproducibility and scientific ethics in three contexts: curricular enrichment for undergraduates who will integrate the research in their laboratory courses; annual outreach workshops for 7th grade minority students focused on science, technology, engineering and mathematics; and direct participation in research by early-career scientists at postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate levels.

The mobility and mutagenic potential of transposable elements depends on mRNAs produced by synthesis of RNAs (transcription) from the elements themselves. This transcription step is a key control point for regulating transposable element mobility. Previous work has shown that transcription of transposable elements is turned off by small RNAs, which initiate silencing by a post-transcriptional interference mechanism that transitions to transcriptional-level silencing. This project will reproduce key aspects of that previous work and will apply modern technological capabilities to produce higher-value datasets that will be analyzed in creative and innovative ways to determine precisely how RNA interference is targeted to a particular transcript and how RNA-directed DNA methylation and transcriptional-level repression are established to produce trans-generational epigenetic silencing of transposable elements. Data and protocols will be broadly disseminated via open-access routes to enable the reproducibility of the research. The results should provide not only new understanding of how RNA-mediated silencing occurs, but also clues about how such silencing could be prevented. These insights could have practical consequences for genetically engineering plants with agronomic benefit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of NSF Federal Award 1908521 was to re-evaluate key findings in the field of plant epigenetics after several publications in the field were in question due to academic misconduct. These publications had formed the basis of the plant epigenetics field, and we sought to perform unambiguous tests to determine what findings could be independently verified. In one-by-one fashion we retested several key findings using improved technology, some of which was first developed for this project. Through the publications and presentations of our data, we have determined which findings are reproducible, solidifying this base data for the rest of the field to build upon. In addition, training in data misconduct and manipulation was provided to undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral researchers and scientific staff within the host lab, at The Ohio State University and at the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center. 

Along the way, we made unexpected novel discoveries, including that fragments of tRNA molecules can trigger epigenetic silencing and that a protein called ALY1 is involved in epigenetic silencing. We also developed technology to inexpensively assay DNA methylation at a much deeper level, released programs to harvest more data out of these experiments, and released a new and improved annotation of the repetitive regions of the world’s premiere model plant genome. 

The major discovery of this project came when we sought to understand how foreign DNA (which includes mobile genetic elements and transgenes) is initially targeted for epigenetic silencing and DNA methylation. Most of what we know about plant epigenetics and DNA methylation pathways is how their cyclical reinforcing nature is maintained, so we instead focused on the initiation of these processes, a critical unanswered question. Our findings provide a mechanistic framework for how transgenes (or other foreign DNA) can enter a plant unmethylated and quickly be targeted for methylation. Previous models in the literature were insufficient to answer this question. Importantly, we find that the multi-subunit protein complex Polymerase V (Pol V) is absolutely necessary for the initiation of DNA methylation. We reported on how Pol V is targeted to new locations of the genome, in order to start the process of chromatin modification that leads to epigenetic silencing. Understanding the mechanism of Pol V recruitment to new target DNA is critical for the future engineering of genomes. Further, this discovery highlights the importance of understanding how the expression of transgenes and their transcripts are initially targeted for degradation into small RNAs, as these molecules are the key determinants for silencing. We show that avoidance of small RNA production is the best path forward for efficiently expressing transgenes in genetically modified crops. Understanding the recruitment of Pol V and the production of siRNAs are paramount to further genome engineering and helping crops to overcome future stresses, either by designating regions of the genome for silencing evasion or triggering silencing in other regions of the genome.
